Title: Can the way pigs are handled alter behavioural and physiological measures of affective state?
Authors: Ricard Carreras, Laura Arroyo, Eva Mainau, Daniel Valent, Anna Bassols, Antoni Dalmau, Luigi Faucitano, Xavier Manteca, Antonio Velarde
Supporting quotes for "Number of ambiguo: - "At the end of the reminder sessions, each pig was individually subjected to the CBT where a bucket containing two pieces of chopped apple that were accessible by the pig was placed in the middle of the pen. The test ended once the pig had finished eating the chopped apples or 90 s after the pig had entered the test pen. The latency to contact the bucket was recorded as in the previous sessions."
Reasoning for "Number of ambiguous cues":
The paper states that in the cognitive bias test (CBT), pigs were trained to discriminate between a bucket with or without access to chopped apples, which were the positive and negative cues, respectively. The paper does not explicitly state the number of different ambiguous cues used in the CBT, but it does provide details on the test procedure:

"At the end of the reminder sessions, each pig was individually subjected to the CBT where a bucket containing two pieces of chopped apple that were accessible by the pig was placed in the middle of the pen. The test ended once the pig had finished eating the chopped apples or 90 s after the pig had entered the test pen. The latency to contact the bucket was recorded as in the previous sessions."

This indicates that there was only one ambiguous cue used in the CBT - the bucket containing the chopped apples, which was placed in the middle of the pen. The paper does not mention any other ambiguous cues being used.

Title: Effect of gender and halothane genotype on cognitive bias and its relationship with fear in pigs
Authors: Ricard Carreras, Laura Arroyo, Eva Mainau, Raquel Pe Ña, Anna Bassols, Antoni Dalmau, Luigi Faucitano, Xavier Manteca, Antonio Velarde
Supporting quotes for "Number of ambiguo:
- "After the reminder sessions, each pig was individually subjected to a CBT that finished when the pig ate the chopped apples or 90 s after the pig had entered the test pen."
  - "At 19 weeks of age, pigs were trained and tested individually for the CB according to the methodology described by Carreras et al. (2015). Twelve training sessions were performed, 6 with access and 6 without access to chopped apples (A and NA sessions, respectively)."
Reasoning for "Number of ambiguous cues":
The paper does not explicitly state the "Number of ambiguous cues" used in the cognitive bias test. However, it does provide details on the training and testing procedure:

"At 19 weeks of age, pigs were trained and tested individually for the CB according to the methodology described by Carreras et al. (2015). Twelve training sessions were performed, 6 with access and 6 without access to chopped apples (A and NA sessions, respectively)."
This indicates that there were two types of cues used during the training sessions - one with access to food (A) and one without access to food (NA).

"After the reminder sessions, each pig was individually subjected to a CBT that finished when the pig ate the chopped apples or 90 s after the pig had entered the test pen."
During the actual cognitive bias test (CBT), the pigs were presented with a single ambiguous cue, which was the bucket containing the chopped apples.

Therefore, the "Number of ambiguous cues" used in the judgement bias trials was 1.

Title: Effects of Cage Enrichment on Behavior, Welfare and Outcome Variability in Female Mice
Authors: Jeremy D Bailoo, Eimear Murphy, Maria Boada-Saña, Justin A Varholick, Sara Hintze, Caroline Baussière, Kerstin C Hahn, Christine Göpfert, Rupert Palme, Bernhard Voelkl, Hanno Würbel
Reasoning for "Number of ambiguous cues":
To determine the number of ambiguous cues used in the judgment bias task, I will look for relevant quotes in the paper:
To assess judgment biases, we developed a task which integrates active trial initiation into a spatial Go/No Go task (see Supplementary Figure S6 ). Each apparatus consisted of a rectangular arena with a row of nine goal-holes at one end (five of which were used for this task), and a trapezoid-shaped area containing a nosepoke at the opposite end.
This quote indicates that the task used 5 goal-holes, which would correspond to 5 ambiguous cues.
Once animals had learned this discrimination, ambiguous test trials with open goal-holes at three equidistant intermediate locations between the extreme ends, were interspersed among Go and No-Go trials, across six test sessions.
This quote further confirms that there were 3 ambiguous cues used in the judgment bias task.
